description: From Middle English omissioun, from Old French omission, from Late Latin omissio, omissionem, from Latin omitto.

entries.meaning: (uncountable) The act of neglecting to perform an action one has an obligation to do.
examples: E&O insurance (for errors and omissions) covers both errors of commission and errors of omission.

entries.meaning: (countable) An instance of those acts, or the thing left out thereby; something deleted or left out.
examples: The suspicious omissions in the new edition of the book attracted claims of censorship.
The lack of a sponge count was an omission by the surgical team.

entries.meaning: (grammar) The shortening of a word or phrase, using an apostrophe ( ' ) to replace the missing letters, often used to approximate the sound of speech or a specific dialect.
